topics.body:
I have a complicated relationship with fringe beliefs. On the one hand I love stuff like UFO lore, bigfoot, ghost stories and secret societies, but on the other it pisses me off when I see people making money by cynically exploiting people's genuine if absurd belief in these things.

I also tend to get mouth frothingly furious when people bring truly horrific events into their conspiracy theories. The fastest way to piss me off to the point of physical violence is to claim that 9/11 was an inside job. I have, no joking, hit people in the mouth for that horse shit.

And yet more than anything else I adore secret society conspiracy theories. I will read anything about the Illuminati, that shit is like catnip for me.

Thinking about this statement, I realize a lot of it also applies to my view of religion. I like the imagry and the lore, and if you've got a story about the really batshit parts of the Bible then I am all over that, however I get furious when people use religion to try to impose their occasionally monstrous moral and political views on the populace at large, or who interpret their world view entirely through a narrow religious lens. I also despise people who make a fortune exploiting the faith of others.

I some times think that there is a part of me that really, really wants to be a believer. I miss the certainty that came with being one, but a larger part of me cannot be, not because of my intellect, which is nothing to write home about as anyone who has interacted with me for any length of time can attest, but because I just can't believe anymore. In anything. There isn't really an ideology left in me anymore, I'm too aware of my own ignorance.

[bq="gasmaskangel"]"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/52f9be8963687253712b0100#post_52f9be8963687253712b0100
Correct me if I'm wrong but didn't Japan follow a similar policy until the dutch essentially forced their way in?[/bq]

Pretty much. But they shut 'er down after the Ming set up shop and the clans all bent the knee to a new Shogunate. And by that point they were already trading with the Dutch out of Nagaski (I think) and Korea and China (for a time).

The Japanese maintained a strong-armed isolationist and protectionist policy for a long-ass time. It wasn't until the US sent over a ship to force them to open their ports in the mid 19th-century they got around to integrating into the world. And then they had a minor civil war and the Emperor went on his way so that his son/grandson could burn the Pacific.

Because Japanese nationalist policy dawg.
